There is before all men always the problem of the immediate future calling for decision, and when between paths equally righteous, equally shrewd, the choice must depend on the mere prob— ability of unknown results, the baffled mind is certainly permitted by the pro— mises of Jesus to rest in his prescience, warranted, however small the issue, in humbly expecting to see the colt tied, or the man bearing the waterpot; but he who has truly studied the great lessons of worldly experience and the drama of Jesus’ life, will not boast himself in this guidance, perceiving that the Spirit help- ing infirmities is hampered by the great- ness of the infirmities.
